abstract.text: A class that describes the pattern for a recurring event.

inlineContent.text: After you create a recurrence rule, assign it to an event with the method of
Recurrence rules can have an end, represented by an
object. The end can be based on a specific date or a maximum number of occurrences.
It is currently not possible to directly modify an
or any of its properties. This functionality is achieved by creating a new
and setting an event or reminder to use the newly created rule.

abstract.text: Create, view, and edit calendar and reminder events.
A class that represents an event in a calendar.
An abstract superclass for all EventKit classes that have persistent instances.
A class that represents the day of the week.
A class that defines the end of a recurrence rule.
The frequency for recurrence rules.
A class that describes the pattern for a recurring event.
The identifier for the recurrence rule’s calendar.
The days of the month associated with the recurrence rule, as an array of
objects.
The days of the week associated with the recurrence rule, as an array of
objects.
The days of the year associated with the recurrence rule, as an array of
objects.
Indicates which day of the week the recurrence rule treats as the first day of the week.
The frequency of the recurrence rule.
Initializes and returns a recurrence rule with a given frequency and additional scheduling information.
Initializes and returns a simple recurrence rule with a given frequency, interval, and end.
Specifies how often the recurrence rule repeats over the unit of time indicated by its frequency.
The months of the year associated with the recurrence rule, as an array of
objects.
Indicates when the recurrence rule ends.
An array of ordinal numbers that filters which recurrences to include in the recurrence rule’s frequency.
The weeks of the year associated with the recurrence rule, as an array of
objects.
An object that indicates whether modifications should apply to a single event or all future events of a recurring event.
A deprecated function.
Set up an event or reminder that repeats.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
